newsitem.title: INDIA: India to pay 600 rupees bonus on wheat purchases.
newsitem.headline: India to pay 600 rupees bonus on wheat purchases.

text.p: Indian government ministers on Tuesday agreed to pay a 600 rupees bonus per tonne to farmers, for the wheat it procures from them, in addition to the current purchase price of 4,150 rupees.

"The cabinet in its meeting held today has decided that the farmers will be paid a central bonus of 600 rupees per tonne in addition to the minimum support price for wheat procured for the central pool during the 1997/98 (April-March) season," a government statement said.
The bonus will be payable on the wheat offered for sale to the procurement agencies for the central pool upto June 10, 1997, the statement said.

Newspapers last month reported that Prakash Singh Badal, who heads the agriculturally-rich state of Punjab, had threatened to curb procurement in his state if the government did not raise procurement prices to 5.25 rupees from 4.15 rupees per kg.
Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda had urged Badal to "cooperate" in wheat procurement.
The government buys wheat to build up its buffer stocks, which it then uses to control prices by releasing stocks through a state-run distribution system.
The statement said the cabinet has also decided to continue the ban on export of wheat and wheat products in 1997/98.
"It has also been decided that the licensing and stock holding limits of wheat would continue in 1997/98 season also," the statement said.
